task_overview: Compare observational eBOSS DR14 P(k) data with theoretical predictions from wCDM, LCDM+massive neutrinos, and LCDM models, then run MCMC for LCDM+massive neutrinos model parameters.

physics_notes.neutrino_suppression: Massive neutrinos suppress the matter power spectrum on scales smaller than their free-streaming scale. The suppression is approximately Delta P/P ~ -8 * f_nu where f_nu = Omega_nu/Omega_m (Bird et al. 2012, 1109.4416). For sum_m_nu = 0.06 eV, f_nu ~ 0.004, giving ~3% suppression.
physics_notes.wCDM_effect: A dark energy equation of state w != -1 modifies the expansion history and hence the growth of structure. w > -1 (less negative) leads to less suppression of structure growth at late times (slightly more power at large scales). w < -1 leads to more suppression.
physics_notes.N_eff_effect: Increasing N_eff increases the radiation density, shifting matter-radiation equality to later times, which suppresses power on small scales and shifts the turnover of P(k).

actionable_steps: Step 1: Load eBOSS DR14 P(k) data from the specified file. Expect columns: k [h/Mpc], P(k) [Mpc/h]^3, possibly error bars.

Step 2: Compute theoretical P(k) for three models using CLASS or CAMB: (a) LCDM with Planck 2018 best-fit, (b) LCDM+massive neutrinos with sum_m_nu=0.15 eV, N_eff=3.046, (c) wCDM with w=-0.9. Plot all together with data.
Step 3: Set up MCMC with 3 free parameters (sigma8, sum_m_nu, N_eff) fitting to eBOSS P(k) data. Use Planck priors as specified. Fix other cosmological parameters.
Step 4: Run MCMC (small run: 16 walkers, 2000 steps, 500 burn-in).
Step 5: Analyze chains with GetDist, produce triangle plot of posterior distributions, report best-fit values and uncertainties.
